material.name: LiMnO2
material.purity: phase purity established by powder X-ray diffraction

techniques.name: Powder neutron diffraction
techniques.parameters: POLARIS diffractometer at ISIS pulsed source

challenge.description: The resulting products from synthesis using aqueous solutions often have stoichiometries differing from LiMnO2, contain water or protons, are of poor crystallinity, or do not maintain their structure during cycling.
challenge.impact: These issues compromise the material's performance and stability as a rechargeable battery electrode.

solution.description: The authors succeeded in preparing layered, anhydrous, and stoichiometric LiMnO2 by ion exchange from NaMnO2.
solution.methodology: Sodium compound (NaMnO2) was synthesized via solid-state reaction, followed by ion exchange with an excess of LiCl or LiBr in n-hexanol at 145-150°C for 6-8 hours.
solution.effectiveness: The resulting LiMnO2 was confirmed to be stoichiometric, anhydrous, and structurally analogous to LiCoO2, with good stability during cycling.

evidence.source: Text description and synthesis details in the provided document.
evidence.data: Phase purity was established by powder X-ray diffraction, and the layered structure was confirmed by powder neutron diffraction.

context.material_properties: Layered structure, stoichiometric composition, and anhydrous nature.
context.experimental_conditions: Ion exchange performed at 145-150°C in n-hexanol for 6-8 hours.
context.application_relevance: Improved structural integrity and stability make the material suitable as a positive electrode in rechargeable lithium batteries.

challenge.description: Capacity decline observed during cycling, particularly when cycling over both voltage plateaus.
challenge.impact: Capacity fade reduces the practical utility of the material as a rechargeable battery cathode.

solution.description: The authors noted that the voltage range had not been optimized and suggested that confining cycling to one voltage plateau could mitigate capacity fade.
solution.methodology: Preliminary cycling data were collected to evaluate performance, and the authors proposed further optimization of the voltage range.
solution.effectiveness: While the layered structure was retained during cycling, the capacity decline indicates that further optimization is needed for practical applications.

evidence.source: Cycling data and discussion in the provided document.
evidence.data: X-ray diffraction showed retention of the layered structure during lithium removal and reinsertion, but capacity decline was observed.

context.material_properties: Layered structure with voltage plateaus during cycling.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling performed at a constant current density of 0.5 mA/cm² between 3.4 and 4.3 V.
context.application_relevance: Capacity retention is critical for the material's viability as a cathode in rechargeable lithium batteries.
